div.p: 1. IV:30. Friday.

Observed the rising of the Sun, as I have been enabled to do almost every day of the month of November.— The Southing of the Sun is perceptible from day to day. The disk is here just 3 minutes in rising— I have marked in Charcoal over the bedchamber door the line formed by the Sunbeams on the 3d. of November— The 4th. 6th. and 8th. of November, are the days upon which the Sun’s Southing seen from the Northeastern chamber window of the Presidents House rises directly behind the three domes of the Capitol— He rises returning Northward in order inverted, behind the same three domes on the 2d. 4th. and 6th. of February.— From our eastern chamber entry window, the Sun first appears on the 25th of November through two opposite Lutheran windows of an house about 200 yards east of ours— Dr Mayo came this morning with his subscription Book for his sketches of 8 years at Washington, which Lucas at Baltimore is to publish for him; and I subscribed for one copy.— He said he should offer the Subscription book to the President— Mr Charles Sumner of Boston, Son of the Sheriff of the County of Suffolk had called here twice yesterday when I was not at home, and came again this morning. He is a lawyer, and has published Reports of the decisions of the United States Circuit Court in Massachusetts; and has also acted as an assistant to Judge Story as Dane Professor of Law at Cambridge.— He is now going to France, England, Germany and Italy—to make himself acquainted with the Systems of administering the Law in those Countries, and with the ultimate object of comparison between those Systems— I promised him Letters and to leave them at Gadsbys Hotel, his lodgings, if I could write them in time—he was going at 5 this afternoon in the Cars to Baltimore— But I had not the time, for an old Scotchman named Lindsey came and consumed the remainder of the morning with a dissertation upon Silk-worms and Silk— He bred in this City about one Million of Silk worms this Summer, from which he raised about 14. pounds avoirdupois of Silk—besides presents that he has made here, and others sent to his friends in Scotland— He was clad from head to foot in garments of coarse silk manufactured from the cocoons of his own worms— He brought with him some samples of his sewing Silk, and a pair of Socks, of the same material.— He gave me many details of the manner of breeding the worms, which if I had memory left I should commit to it, but which I shall forget to morrow— He projects a memorial to Congress for patronage to the breeding of Silk worms, and the manufacture of silk— To which end I promised all my aid, worth exactly nothing— I called again at the Treasury Department, and again Mr Woodbury was with the President. At Major Nourse’s Office, but he had no bills for Specie— After dinner Mr Frye called and spent an hour with us— Then Mrs Stewart, with Mr and Mrs Parnell came in— They are upon a visit here with an infant daughter about 6 months old, from Ireland— Parnell married Delia Stewart in July 1835 when he was here with Lord Powerscourt— Finally I had a visit from Mrs Madison’s son Todd who
who left with me three manuscript volumes of his writings— The same which he had once before lent to me last Spring— One of the volumes contains Letters from Mr Madison, written during the revolutionary war, and one of the Letters, contains reflections upon the character and capacity of the late judge Dana injurious to his memory, which I had advised Mr Todd, to leave out or modify to avoid giving unnecessary pain to his surviving family and friends— He now requested me to mark with a pencil the passages that I thought it would be advisable to strike out, and said he would call again for the manuscript to-morrow— There was a cry of fire this Evening—a false alarm— I began making out a list of the Petitions against the annexation of Texas to the Union, received since the close of the last Session— Northern light. No fire in my chamber.
2. III:30. Saturday.

The Birth-day of my eldest Grand-daughter Mary-Louisa Adams, daughter of my dear departed Son, John; born in the President’s House, and this day nine years of age.— She and her younger Sister, born at Quincy 10. September 1830 have been brought up in my family, as children, and their mother has always been to me as a daughter— I finished this morning the list of Petitions against the annexation of Texas to this Union, received since I ceased presenting similar Petitions at the late Session of Congress— They are 33 in number; and I have a few others upon the subject of Slavery— I called at the Treasury Department and left with Mr Woodbury the Letter which I last received from Russell Freeman relating to his application for re-appointment to the Office of Collector of the Customs at New-Bedford— I told him that I performed this Office as a friend of Mr Russell, and at his desire, without wishing to interfere with the appointment— I had not much acquaintance with Mr Freeman, but had been intimate with two of his elder brothers especially with one of them, Nathaniel Freeman, my Classmate at the University; afterwards a member of Congress but who died in the first year of this century— But of Mr Russell Freeman’s present pretensions I did not wish to judge— He had politically been a friend to me, and of the party formerly called republican— And had eight years since been removed from the office to which he wished now to be restored— In his Letter to me he expressed some apprehension that a charge of intemperate habits had been or might be urged against him; but he affirmed not only that he had been for years a member of a Temperance Society; but had been a delegate from it to a general Temperance Convention in Massachusetts last year.— Mr Woodbury said he had never heard any charge of intemperance against Mr Freeman. Nor any other excepting that of his being deaf— I said that Mr Freeman did not deny that, but alleged that it had not disqualified from performing to the entire satisfaction of the people at New-Bedford, the Office of Collector; but had in some degree disqualified him for professional practice as a lawyer, and therefore made the emoluments of Office more necessary to him for the support of his family— He said he would lay
lay Mr Freeman’s Letter before the President, As he had already submitted to him Mr Freeman’s other papers that I had left with him.— That Mr Williams the present collector, had been a speculator in copper, and some months since was supposed to be immensely rich; and it was then expected that he would decline a re-appointment— But it was now said the copper speculation had failed and that Mr Williams wished to be re-appointed— Mr Woodbury made some enquiries of me, about the Dighton-rock; and particularly if I had ever seen it— He said there was a new Antiquarian Society in Denmark, which had already published some dissertation about supposed Norwegian discoveries in this hemisphere in the 11th. century— I suppose a new resurrection of Prince Madoc— I said I had no faith in any of these ante Columbian discoveries of America, from Plato’s Atlantis, and the captive ten tribes of Israel down to Prince Madoc.— At Major Nourse’s Office and then at the Bank of Washington. The premium on specie 5 1/2 per cent— At Niles’s Register Office— He gave me Newspapers containing Letters from J. C. Calhoun—John P. King; and H. Legare, all upon the sub-Treasury Mr Frye, and Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith dined and spent the Evening with us— Mrs Frye was detained at home in attendance of her son T. B. J. Frye, who is confined with an abscess under his arm.
3. VI: Sunday.

At the Presbyterian Church heard a Stranger preach from Galatians 6.14. [“]But God forbid that I should glory, save in the cross of our Lord Jesus Christ”—the first part of the verse— The preacher soon gave notice that by the cross of Jesus Christ, was understood what was usually called the Atonement, and then came the whole presbyterian creed— The fallen condition of man—his utter inability to do any thing for his own Salvation— The necessity of a vicarious sacrifice to atone for the irremissible crimes, and the ignominious death of almighty God, as a malefactor— I can hardly preserve my gravity, when I observe the fervour and seeming sincerity with which these young men dwell upon this argument as if they really believed what they say— I believe that Christ died for man as Warren died for his Country— Why, in the Counsels of divine Providence his death was necessary, transcends my capacity of comprehension— If as the Calvinists believe, Christ was incarnate God, his death was the death only of the mortal part—of man not of God—that the Soul of man suffers in its separation from the body, I perceive and understand. But that omnipotence should suffer is incomprehensible and incredible to me— That he should suffer by his own decree to save man his own creature from the penalty of his own Law, is as inconceivable to me, as that he should be his own Son— That such a bundle of absurdities as the abuse of humane reason has drawn from the gospel of John, and the Epistles of Paul, should after nineteen centuries of Christianity overspread the intellect of so large a portion of mankind is a mortifying and a melancholy contemplation— That it should have subdued and still hold in subjection minds of capacity so far surpassing my own is a humiliating consideration. Indeed
Indeed almost the only instruction that I ever gather from the pulpit is humility, and the perverseness of my nature revolts continually against that.— The Calvinistic doctrine of human depravity, so far as concerns the inspirations of the heart, is I fear too near the truth— I have much to answer for before God— I hope not much before man— God forbid that I should glory in any thing— St. Paul might glory in the cross of Jesus Christ; for he had laboured faithfully and effectively to achieve its victory over the world—but if the cross of Christ was necessary to my Salvation, it affords me cause rather for mourning than for glory— Mr Asbury Dickins, now Secretary to the Senate paid me a visit this afternoon— He has recently returned from an excursion to Philadelphia after the close of the late Session of Congress— My wife and Mary with the two children attended Church at St. John’s this morning— I went with Mary-Louisa only after dinner— Mr Hawley read the Evening service for Advent Sunday, omitting the Psalms of the day, and the first Lesson which is the 2d Chapter of Isaiah— His Sermon was from Isaiah 55.8. “For my thoughts are not your thoughts, neither are your ways my ways, saith the Lord— 9. For as the heavens are higher than the earth, so are my ways higher than your ways, and my thoughts than your thoughts” We spent the Evening at Mr Frye’s— Thomas is confined to his chamber— Mr Frye had received within a few days the final volumes of the writings of Washington—that is the 11th. and 12th. and the first volume which contains the Life— Mr Frye had also two Letters from Arthur Lee, and some other papers relating to the controversy about Jonathan Williams’s accounts in 1778 and 1779.— After returning home I read a few pages in the 2d. Volume of Burr’s life.
4. IV. Monday
25th. Congress, 2d. Session.

lg.l: Almighty Father! look in Mercy down!
Oh! grant me Virtue, to perform my part—
The Patriot’s fervour, and the Statesman’s art—
And with success my stedfast purpose crown.
Direct me to the paths of pure Renown
Guide my frail bark, by Truth’s unerring chart
Inspire my Soul, and purify my heart—
In thought, word, deed, preserve me from thy frown.
My Country’s weal! by that my polar Star
Justice—the rock of ages—is thy Law
And when thy Summons calls me to thy bar
Be this my plea, thy gracious smile to draw
That all my ways, to Justice were inclin’d
And all my aims—the blessing of mankind—

div.p:
Morning visit from Messrs. Cranston of Rhode-Island, Davies, Potts, and Toland of Pennsylvania, all members of the House of Representatives— I walked to the Capitol and at 12. Noon James K. Polk, Speaker of the House of Representatives took the Chair, and called the House to order— The roll was called alphabetically by States, beginning with Maine—163 members answered to their names, and several others came in after their names were called and before the House adjourned— Their names were entered for the Journal— Archibald Yell of Arkansas, appeared, claimed his seat, and was sworn— His case is precisely the same with that of the two members from Mississippi who at the late extra Session, were declared by Resolution of the House, members for the whole 25th Congress— He was elected for the special Session, and attended it, without question upon the legality of his election— The regular election has since been held, and he was chosen again— The usual message was sent to the Senate that a quorum of the House was assembled and ready to proceed to business and a similar message was received from the Senate— A joint Committee was ordered in each House to wait upon the President of the United States, and inform him that Congress was assembled, and ready to receive any Communication from him— The usual order was taken, that the members should be supplied with three daily Newspapers— Elijah Whittlesey moved that the standing Committees should now be appointed, and then that his motion should be considered to-morrow— Cushman of New Hampshire moved to postpone the Consideration till Thursday— Whittlesey then made a hortatory and objurgative Speech, and called for the yeas and nays; upon which Cushman softened down to Wednesday, and finally agreed upon to-morrow— Underwood of Kentucky was for discussing the rules of the House again; and upon being told that the Rules adopted at the first Session of a Congress were Rules for the whole Congress, he offered a long Resolution for a new Rule to publish the lists of Yeas and Nays upon all questions, and send them after every Session to their Constituents— This was ordered to be printed. He moved also a call upon the Secretary of War, about the employment of Indians in the Florida War— This lies over one day.— The House adjourned about one— I wrote a few lines to my Son— Mr Fletcher gave me a small volume from James Savage, for Mrs Tudor.— Henley’s trial; belonging to the Boston Athenaeum. He asked me for my Speech— Mr Cushing told me he had lost part of his baggage, in the Cars from Baltimore— Returning home from the Capitol, I met in the yard Mr Legare of South-Carolina, who had just come in; and was going to the House— After dinner, a Quaker by the name of Adam Brooks of South
South Scituate, in my District, brought some samples of sewing silk and of silk handkerchiefs, made by himself and his wife, from silk worms of their own raising— He has invented a machine, for spinning the silk from the Cocoon, for which he has a patent, and which he proposes to exhibit working to-morrow in the Rotunda at the Capitol. His machine and his and his wife’s silks were exhibited at the late Mechanics Fair in Boston, and again at that of the American Institute at New-York. I told him I had received the pamphlet containing the proceedings at the Exhibition of the Mechanical Fair at Boston, with Governor Everett’s address, which he said was excellent— He asked to see the pamphlet, and pointed out to me three several places where his machine and his silks were noticed with commendation.— Mrs Adams gave him, her draw full of Cocoons, which she raised three years ago— I took the trial of Henley into Mrs Tudor— She was in her chamber unwell and could not see me. Mrs Tudor, and Mr and Mrs Parnell were just leaving the dinner table; and he had the baby in his arms.— After returning I attempted to read a few pages of Burr’s Life—but was too weary— The children went to school this morning to Madame Brechard.

5. III.45. Tuesday. Sun rose 7:3: between 2 Chimneys.— Fire in my chamber this eve. Walk to the Capitol— Overtook and walked with C. C Cambreleng. Talk about the weather and Canada; where there are grave disturbances, and even insurrection: of the causes of which I know nothing; and of which I found he knew very little— As we were walking up the steps of the Capitol Yard we met David B. Odgen, a New-York whig of considerable note— As he passed us Cambreleng said to me— Why, he has got a new suit of Clothes on the strength of his success— This was Cambreleng’s characteristic manner, intending to rally me in the person of Ogden, as I happened to have on a new Coat— He has been touched to the quick, during the recess, by the figure he makes in my Speech on Nouns, Pronouns, Verbs and Adverbs, and vented his spleen anonymously, in the New-York Evening Post— The House at Noon was called to order, and Mr Muhlenberg of Pennsylvania reported from the joint Committee to wait on the President, that he had informed them he would make a Communication to both Houses of Congress this day at 12 O’Clock— The message was immediately afterwards delivered by his Son, and private SecretaryVan Buren— The reading of it by the Clerk took an hour and a quarter; after which Haynes of Georgia moved that it be referred to a Committee of the whole house on the state of the Union,—which was agreed to—as was his motion that 15000 copies of the Message with the Documents, and 5000 copies without the Documents, be printed for the use of the members— Elisha Whittlesey moved to reduce the whole to 10000 copies with the Documents, for economy’s sake, and to return to
to old habits— But Haynes said he had proposed only the same numbers printed of the Message at the opening of the special Session; and he thought there was at least as much reason for printing an equal number of this— Of the immense importance of the Message, he would advert only to that part of it which related to Mexico— Haynes had Texas and Slavery in his head, though in the Message there was not a word about either.— Haynes’s motion was carried, and the 5000 copies are to be delivered within two days— The House immediately adjourned— In the Rotunda, I found Adam Brooks working with his spinning and twisting machine; and I introduced him to Mr Lindsey who was there— He gave me a paper with two samples of his sewing silk as a present to Mrs Adams— I wrote Letters of introduction for Charles Sumner, to Daniel Brent and Robert Walsh at Paris, and to Thomas Aspinwall, our Consul at London— I attempted to read a few pages of Burr’s Life, but was constrained by drowsiness to desist— Mrs Tudor sent me Coll. Henley’s Trial; her husband’s diploma as a member of the order of Cincinnati, and some other documents for a Petition to Congress for the Commutation— The Message gave me a fit of melancholy for the future fortunes of the Country— Cunning and duplicity pervade every line of it. The sacrifice of the rights of Northern freedom to Slavery and the South, and the purchase of the West by the plunder of public Lands, is the combined system which it discloses;— It is the system of Jackson’s Message of December 1832 covered with a new coat of varnish— Jackson was dashing and daring— This man is insinuating and plausible— Their characters are comprized in the names of Shakespear’s two catchpoles Phang and Snare.
6. III:45. Wednesday.

No fire till Evening— Walk to the Capitol—part of the way with Jenifer— I asked him if the death of Governor Kent, the late Senator from Maryland would be noticed in the House— He said he had found that it was not usual for either House of Congress to notice the decease of a member of the other, during the recess. H.R.U.S— That is in the House.— There were several Resolutions offered. That of E. Whittlesey was with his own consent postponed till to-morrow—falling into the old beaten track—the error of which consists, first in parceling out all the business of the House among standing Committees—secondly in authorizing the Speaker to appoint them all; and to designate their Chairmen; and thirdly in that domination of party Spirit which rules over the House, the Speaker and the Committees, the irradicable infirmity of human nature— It would perhaps be possible to reduce the number of the standing Committees, or to appoint them by lot— They might indeed be all appointed on the first day of the Session, and ought to be— The consequence of the present mode
mode of transacting business, is almost a total loss of the first week of the Session.— Mr Underwood’s motion, that an addition should be made to the 83d. rule of the House, requiring the Clerk to compile a separate Journal of all the lists of yeas and nays to be distributed at the close of every Session among the People was taken up— Feebly opposed by Haynes, Rencher and Boon—forcibly by Hamer—to all of whom Underwood replied, without support from any quarter— At Hamer’s motion it was laid on the table— The other resolution offered by Underwood, calling on the Secretary of War for information concerning the employment of Indians in the Florida-War against Indians, was adopted without opposition, with an amendment, proposed by Briggs and accepted by Underwood, requiring a statement of the expense of these Indian auxiliaries— The Reports from the Secretary of the Treasury on the Finances, and on the condition of the depository Banks were received— Cambreleng moved the reference of the first to the Committee of Ways and Means— The Speaker reminded him that the standing Committees were not yet appointed— The report was laid on the table, and 10,000 copies ordered to be printed— The Treasurer’s Accounts were reported in manuscript, contrary to the practice which has been heretofore, to report them ready printed—but for the last two quarters they are not completed— Snyder of Illinois offered a Resolution, that the Act of the special Session, postponing to the 1st. of January 1839. the payment of the 4th. instalment of the deposit with the States directed by the act of 23. June 1836 be repealed. It lies over one day.— W. Cost Johnson offered a Resolution calling on the Secretary of the Navy for information, why the South Sea exploring expedition has not sailed. Between one and two O’Clock the House adjourned— I enclosed to Mr Charles Sumner at New-York three Letters of Introduction to Paris and London— In the Evening I wrote to Mr Philip Ammidon, and read in the second Volume of Burr’s life— Matthew L. Davis, its author is here, as he has been during several late Sessions, as a Correspondent of the New-York Courier and Enquirer.— He writes under the signature of the Spy in Washington— He came to my seat this morning, and I told him I was reading his book— His account of the origin of the political parties in New-York, during the revolutionary War, and of their subsequent bearing on the fortunes of Burr, throws some light upon the history of the time— The failure of my father’s re-election in 1801. was the joint work of Burr and Alexander Hamilton, and it is among the most remarkable examples of divine retributive justice that the result to them was the murder of one of them by the other in a duel, and the irretrievable ruin of the murder by the very accomplishment of his intrigues— Even handed Justice never held a better balanced scale.— Between my father and Jefferson, the final decision of that same Justice was reserved, for a higher state of being— The double-dealer succeeded in this world; yet his death-bed was less tranquil and composed than that of him whom he had wronged— Jefferson’s hypocrisy and duplicity in the scenes of his election, as President, are exposed, in glaring colours in these Volumes; which apparently intended to vindicate the character of Burr do but set the Seal upon his condemnation— But they fix an indelible stain upon that of Jefferson.
7. V:45. Thursday

A young man from the Office of the National Intelligencer brought me a Note from Mr Seaton, asking for the manuscript of my two speeches at the special Session, on the Mississippi election, to be published in the paper to-morrow; which I gave him— I had returned yesterday to Mr Gales the manuscript of Arphaxed Loomis’s speech which immediately preceded mine, and which Gales had lent me— When I reached the Capitol this morning I found the House in Session, the Clock having been set, a quarter of an hour in advance of the City Clocks, generally.— The order for the appointment of the standing Committees was now passed, and Haynes of Georgia moved that the House should now resolve itself into a Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, to take into consideration the President’s Message— It was objected that this had never been done until the appointment of the standing Committees had been made and announced to the House. Haynes did not press his motion, but moved that the Resolutions which he gave notice that he should offer be printed which was agreed to— A message was received from the President with sundry documents, which were laid on the Table— W. Cost Johnson modified his call upon the President for information why the exploring expedition has not sailed, and it was adopted— At 25 minutes past 12 by the Clock the House adjourned— I invited the members of the Massachusetts delegation to meet in the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures and they all attended excepting Mr Borden, whom I had not an opportunity to notify—Briggs—Calhoon, Cushing, Fletcher Grennell, Hastings, Lincoln, Parmenter, Phillips and Reed were there— I told them I had called them together to consult them upon the disposal which should be proposed to be made in the House of the Petitions and Memorials against the annexation of Texas to the Union, of which I had now about forty to present; and also of the various petitions relating to Slavery, of which I had ten or twelve.— The Petitions would be called for next Monday to which day the House had adjourned, and I thought that would be the time for calling up all the Petitions and Memorials on the same Subject; and then by the general order, laid on the table— My own idea and purpose was, in presenting the first Petition to move that it be referred, together with all those on the same subject presented at the special Session, should be referred to a select Committee to consider and report thereon. I did not expect that the House would agree to this motion, but I thought it would be advisable to make it— The Petitions relating to Slavery I thought of moving to refer to the several Committees on the District of Columbia—on the Territories, and of Commerce— I supposed however that the House would pass a Resolution, of the same import with that adopted at both Sessions of the last Congress, that all such petitions, Memorials and papers be laid on the table, without further action upon them by the House— With regard to those against the annexation of Texas to the Union I knew not what course the House would take
take but I thought they should be referred to a select Committee. There was then a discussion of about two hours, in which very little difference of opinion was expressed, excepting by Mr Parmenter, who is a strong friend and supporter of the present Administration— He disagreed to almost all the opinions expressed by the other members and by me, but made no objection to the motions proposed by me to dispose of the Petitions, and declared his willingness to agree to them— Most of the members took part in the discussion, and it was at last unanimously voted that I should make the motions for reference of the several petitions as I had proposed.— Mr Hastings was inclined to have another meeting to consider of the Petitions relating to Slavery, but the other members thought it not necessary— As I was returning home, I passed in the Avenue, by Mrs Macomb without seeing her, till she called me back, and asked me to vote for Mr Fowler as Chaplain to the House, which I promised I would, and told her laughing that she made all our Chaplains— At home I gave some to assorting Petitions to be presented next Monday— Answered a Letter of 9. August last from John Thomas of Kingston, and read 30 pages of Burr’s Life.— The narrative and documents relating to the contested election between Jefferson and Burr for the Presidency of the United States, in February 1801.— The only thing new to me that I find in it is a Letter from Saml. Smith to Richard H. Bayard, and James A. Bayard, the two Sons of the former James A. Bayard, dated in April 1830. advising them to let well enough alone— In 1806 Bayard and Smith had given contradictory depositions, concerning their negotiations with each other at the election of 1801. and each of them had then told me his Story, conformable to their respective depositions.— My wife and Mary spent the Evening at
8. III:45. Friday.

Card from Mr Taliaferro. Morning visit, from Messrs. Slade, Russell, Clay, Milligan, and Phillips— I condoled with Mr Clay on the sudden and melancholy decease of Dr Kent, which he had with great sensibility announced last Tuesday to the Senate. He said he had been much shocked on receiving the intelligence, from a newspaper which was handed to him by a friend as he landed from a Steamboat, at Wheeling— Dr Kent was one of those fortunate men of good understanding courteous manners, placid temper, and pure morals, who glide through the world in the most tempestuous times, with the steady favour of their Countrymen, scarcely affected by the mutability of popular opinions— For the last forty years Doctor Kent has been almost without intermission in public life—as a member of the Maryland Legislature, and of both Houses of Congress, Presidential Elector, and Governor of the State— He was universally respected, and his death is lamented by all who knew him.— Mr Clay spoke to me also of the Mississippi election, which he said was unquestionably illegal— And he said Mr Gholson himself had told him he thought it so.— The most extraordinary
extraordinary fact of the case is, that both Gholson and Claiborne asseverated in the most positive manner in the debate upon their election before the house, that the People of Mississippi at the election in August had universally believed that it was for the whole Congress— I knew that was impossible but there was nobody to contradict them— I told Mr Clay that I was sick of contested elections.— This is the third case since I have been a member of the House unjustly decided— In that of Letcher and Moore the House stultified itself by shrinking from the decision which they had been forced to admit, forced upon them— In that of Graham and Newland, they came within one vote of admitting the intruder, and they excluded the rightful member.— But there has been no prostration of principle equal to that of this decision at the special Session— On the subject of the Banks and their present condition we had some conversation but I could not ascertain how Mr Clay felt upon it, and how far he may be under bank influences— The Convention of Bank delegates at New-York, concluded by calling another convention to meet next April— Mr Clay said that Mr Brockenbrough who was a delegate to that Convention from one of the Virginia Banks and was now returning home had told him there was a considerable manifestation of jealousy manifested between the Banks of New-York and those of Philadelphia, by Mr Gallatin and Mr Eyre— I walked before dinner to College Hill and the Race-ground— I had not been there before for many months— Meridian Hill forms part of those Heights— The house in which I resided from the 3d. of March to the 10th. of June 1829. has left on my mind, associations, deep and distressing beyond any thing else that has ever happened to me throughout my life— This afternoon and Evening I was occupied in making a minute of the Petitions presented by me, at the special Session of Congress, in number 400, which are to be called up next Monday, and in writing an answer long delayed to a Letter from Josiah Savil junr about a bounty land claim— I read a few pages in the life of Burr, closing the account of the Presidential election in 1801.
9. IV.30. Saturday.

The first fall of snow, in quantity just sufficient to whiten the surface of the ground; but the feeling of winter thoroughly pervades the atmosphere— I suffered so much from cold in writing before daylight, that I was obliged to betake myself to the dining room, and to reading in the life of Burr to recover from a shivering fit— Mrs. Stewart came in and spoke about the proposed Petition of her mother for the commutation, for the service of her husband as Judge Advocate General of the army at the commencement of the revolutionary War— I advised that before presenting this petition, Mrs Tudor should wait for the decision upon her Petition
Petition for an allowance of a claim, of about a year’s Salary to her Son William as diplomatic agent in Peru— The two claims if existing together might prove injurious to each other, and have a tendency to defeat both— I gave her two copies of the document just published of his Brazilian Correspondence— I received this morning a Letter from Russel Freeman enclosing two papers with numerous signatures recommending the appointment of him as Collector at New-Bedford; and a sealed Letter from William Foster, addressed to Martin Van Buren, President of the United States— I took that Letter and the two certificates to the President, and delivered them to him. He spoke favourably of Mr Freeman, and said he had endeavoured to prevail upon General Jackson to retain him in office— He added that Mr Woodbury had already communicated to him several other recommendations of Mr Freeman, and that when the time for making the nomination should come, he would give full consideration to his claims— But he said Mr Woodbury had told him he did not know, but believed that Mr Williams the present Collector, having been unfortunate in some Speculations, would wish for reappointment to the Office. I said I had no acquaintance with Mr Williams, and not much with Mr Freeman personally— He had been a member of the Legislature and of the Executive Council of Massachusetts— I had been fifty years ago acquainted with his father, and the intimate friend of his brother, a Classmate of mine at the University, generally considered the first scholar in the Class, and afterwards, a member of Congress though he died young, not much over the age of thirty— I had also been acquainted with a yet older brother as Editor of a newspaper, and of a monthly Magazine in Boston— Mr Russel Freeman, had been first appointed Collector at New-Bedford by Mr Monroe— In December 1828 I nominated him for re-appointment; his Commission being to expire on the 3d. of March 1829. It was one of a multitude of nominations upon which the Senate did not act through the whole Session, and when Jackson came in he nominated Francis Baylies, who was appointed but declined accepting; but recommended Williams— All these proceedings were stimulated by Jackson’s personal malignity to me— Baylies and Williams were federalists rank as the compost of a dunghill—and therefore bitter as wormwood against me— Baylies in 1825 had as a member of Congress voted for Jackson as President, libelled me in the Newspapers and lost his election in consequence— He thought Jackson undervalued him by the offer of the Collectorship of New-Bedford, and Jackson to appease him gave him as a second sop the Office of Chargé d’Affaires at Buenos-Ayres. He went there—stayed there not three months; just long enough to embroil his Country in a senseless and wicked quarrel with that government; and without waiting for orders from his Government demanded his Passports and came home— Nothing but the imbecility of that South-American abortion of a State saved him from indelible disgrace and this Country from humiliation in that concern.— Jackson did not employ him again; and so he turned Bank whig, and now is in deadly opposition to Van Buren— He is one of the most talented and worthless men in
in New England— Russel Freeman had originally been of the democratic party, but had also been and continued to be friendly to me— That was his crime with Jackson who turned him out first to put in Francis Baylies and then Lemuel Williams—Blue-light federalists, but thorough going haters and revilers of me. I said nothing of all this to Mr Van Buren—not a single word even to insinuate the political opinions of either of word—nor a word against Williams or Baylies— We had some conversation about patronage and appointments, upon which his theories and mine do not so well agree as our experience— He says he considers it as a misfortune when any office to be filled by him becomes vacant, and thinks patronage rather a burden than a benefit. I went to the Pension Office and left with the Commissioner Edwards a Letter from Matthias J. Bovee a member of the last Congress from the interior of New-York, concerning the claim of a Widow Lucy Shepherd for a pension— Evening read in Burr’s Life—
10. IV:30. Sunday

Flannels. Heard this morning at the Presbyterian Church Mr Fowler from Romans 2:28 [“]For he is not a Jew, which is one outwardly; neither is that circumcision, which is outward in the flesh— 29— But he is a Jew which is one inwardly; and circumcision, is that of the heart, in the spirit, and not in the letter; whose praise is not of man, but of God.” Mr Fowler’s Discourse was very short, and he descanted upon the peculiar character of the Christian religion as adapting its precepts not only to the actions, but to the thoughts and purposes of man— Whether this property belongs so exclusively to the Christian Religion may be doubted, for it seems included in the doctrine of responsibility to a superior Power, and a future state of retribution— But that it is the great characteristic of Christianity cannot be denied— After dinner at St. John’s Church, Mr Hawley read the Evening service for the second Sunday in advent, omitting the Psalms and the first lesson, and reading by mistake the 10th instead of the 12th. chapter of Romans for the second Lesson— The Sermon was by a person named Wolff a German convert from the Jewish faith, and his text was from Romans 11.25. [“]For I would not, brethren that ye should be ignorant of this mystery, lest ye should be wise in your own conceits: that blindness in part is happened to Israel until the fulness of the Gentiles be come in 26— And so, all Israel shall be saved: as it is written, there shall come out of Zion, the deliverer, and shall turn away ungodliness from Jacob”—and so on to the end of the chapter— The final restoration of the Jews was the thence; and the principal merit of the discourse consisted in a continual text, collated with passages of the prophets Isaiah, Jeremiah, Daniel Zecariah, and Micah, which appear indeed wonderfully adapted to one another— This Mr Wolff is an itinerant missionary and has travelled over all the world preaching his judaic Christianism— He has a coarse, vulgar, not very clearly German-Jewish look—short-sighted, with a frowzy black periwig, and an exceedingly broad
broad German-pronunciation of English, making altogether as ungainly a personage as you would wish to see— The effect of the whole is so ludicrous that it is scarcely possible to refrain from laughing— And he was obliged in the midst of his Sermon to chide the boys in the gallery, who could not garder le serieux. At another time he interrupted himself bent down over the pulpit and said he should like a light; and a lamp was accordingly carried to him— Yet there was with all this a sincerity—a zeal, a vehemence and a penetration of research, and closeness of argument in the discourse deeply impressive, and the like of which I never heard before— Mr Hawley gave notice that he would preach this Evening at Trinity Church and lecture twice a day every day during the ensuing week, at Georgetown, Alexandria, and in this City.— Evening visits from Mr John Connell and Mr John P. Todd, to the latter of whom I returned some of the manuscript papers of Mr Madison which he had left with me—with pencil marks at the passages at which I thought might with advantage be left out. I finished and despatched an answer to a Letter received 4. months since from Mrs Wirt— The Snow all disappeared in the course of this day.
11. VI:30. Monday.

Our visitors last evening kept us up till past eleven O’Clock, and the consequence was a corresponding postponement of my rising hour this morning— Our philosophy was tried this morning by unlucky accident— The Barouche was standing at the door, and having on a pinching pair of new shoes, I was about riding in it to the Capitol— The Coachman Thomas Nelson, left his horses, with the reins in the hands of the black man William to go into the stable to fetch a bear-skin to lay on the floor of the Carriage— While William held the reins a man with a Cart passed by—cracked his whip two or three times—the horses started; the reins broke in William’s hands—away went horses and barouche, raced down two or three Streets—overset, and broke the carriage all to pieces— A new purchase last year, by Mr Frye, and very little used— The third carriage of mine, smashed and ruined within three years by oversetting— I had not seen the Carriage move from the door and after waiting for it a quarter of an hour or more I enquired where it was— Mrs. Adams thought it was in the yard— I went there and called for Thomas— No answer, no barouche and horses— I went into the Streets— Rachel the Cook, was standing at the corner of the house— I asked her if she knew what had become of the barouche— She said Thomas had gone down the Street, with it and William was gone after him— All this happened in the course of a quarter of an hour and I had not a suspicion that any accident had occurred— I thought Thomas had taken the Carriage to the Coachmaker’s for some necessary repair, and walked on to the Capitol— As I turned the corner at Blake’s shop, at the foot of Pennsylvania-Avenue, where there is a stand of Hucks, one of the drivers was telling another as they stood in the street by their vehicles of horses that had run away
run away, overset the Carriage, and broken it all to pieces— The other man asked him to whom the Carriage belonged. He answered in a low tone of voice, and I thought he named me— Still I thought it so impossible that this should have happened, and got to be a matter of talk so near my house, that I thought the man was telling of some disaster that had happened last night and that I had not heard correctly the name he had given as the owner of the Carriage— I did not even stop to ask the man if he had named me, but thinking more of my pinched corns than of the barouche, was sure I had mistaken the name, dismissed the subject from my cogitations, and limped along to the Capitol, expecting all the time that Thomas and the barouche would overtake me—looking occasionally behind to see if they were coming as I had told Rachel to tell Thomas to do when he should return to the House, and still notwithstanding all these warnings, not even surmising the wreck of the carriage, which had taken place— From that time, the conversation between the Hackman at the Corner of the Pennsylvania avenue never presented itself to my thoughts till after I had come home and dined when my wife told me what come to pass; when I could but reflect upon the sluggish torpidity of my own senses, and bless Providence that in this casualty no person, nor even the horses had been hurt; and particularly for my own escape from a heavier calamity, if I had been as I was so near being in the Carriage when the horses started— By a singular coincidence, the children who had missed their morning lesson of reading with me in the Bible, because they had not come down in time before they were obliged to go to school, read after dinner, from the 17th. to the 23d. Psalm— When we came to the 7th. and 8th. verses of the 20th. Psalm— 7. “Some trust in chariots, and some in horses; but we will remember the name of the Lord our God. 8. They are brought down and fallen: but we are risen and stand upright.”— I reminded the children how appropriate this passage was to the event of this day, and how much they should lay it to heart always to rely upon the Providence of God—and Louisa remarked, that it taught us also to be careful in whatever we do— At the House, in reading the Journal, the standing Committees were announced—with very little difference the same as at the special Session— The Speaker gave notice that he should call by the States for Petitions to-morrow— Whittlesey presented a list of claims upon which Bills have heretofore been presented to the House, and moved the reference of them all to the Committee of Claims— Patton moved the extension of the same principle to all the other Committees which was adopted— The house balloted five times for a Chaplain when the Revd. Mrwas elected— Mr Fowler had 47. votes at the first ballot nominated by Mr Garland of Virginia— Mrs Genl. Macomb had stop’d me the other day in the Street, and asked me to vote for him; which I had promised and did.

Sundry Resolutions were offered by the Western Members, for plundering under the name of pre-emption and graduating the prices of the public Lands— Lawler, Chapman, Martin and Lyon of Alabama, ran a race upon this subject— Carter of Tennessee, cut in for a slice of the public domain— W. Cost Johnson, put them in check by having the reference made to the Committee of roads and canals instead of the Committee of Public Lands— I offered a Resolution to instruct the Committee on the District of Columbia to report a Bill prohibiting the Banks in the District of Columbia from making or declaring any dividends of profits to their Stockholders, whenever they suspend specie payments— Patton moved an amendment turning it into an instruction to the Committee to inquire into the expediency of reporting such a Bill— I accepted the amendment, and the Resolution passed— Adjourned a quarter past 3. I went into the Library and consulted the volume of the Revolutionary Diplomatic Correspondence containing the Letters from the Commissioners to France in 1778. to ascertain the appointment of Mr Joshua Johnson as Consul of the United States at Nantes, but could not find it— In the evening I read 30 pages of the Life of Burr. After the contested election in Feby 1801— The correspondence is almost entirely with his daughter who about that time in her 19th. year married Joseph Alston of South-Carolina; a rich Planter, but a very ordinary man— They had after a year’s marriage one Son; and they visited and revisited one another between New-York and North-Carolina.— Mr John Pope of Kentucky took his seat in the house this day.
12. IV:30 Tuesday

Nathaniel Bird, a soldier of the Revolution for whom I drew and presented a Petition to the House last Winter came this morning, to recommend his case to me again— H.R.U.S. Before the Meeting of the House John Reed introduced J. T. Buckingham to me: he is the Editor of the Boston Courier, and a member of the Massachusetts Legislature from Cambridge.— Matthew L. Davis was also on the floor, and I told him I was reading in regular course his life of Burr; and that I had read last Evening to my wife and daughter, to their great amusement, the correspondence about his proposal of marriage to a Lady in Philadelphia in 1802 when he was Vice-President, and that we all thought it the best part of the Book— I asked him who the Lady was— He said he could not tell that; for she was still living and had a family of children— He said some of the Southern Gentlemen blamed him for publishing that part of the Correspondence, as being of too light and frivolous a nature—but there is nothing in the book more characteristic of the man— As soon as the Journal was read, the Speaker called the States for Petitions beginning with Maine— When the turn of Massachusetts came, I waited till all the other members from the State had presented their Petitions, and then offered first all the Petitions and Memorials which I had presented at former Sessions, and which had not been finally acted
acted upon, and had them referred to the appropriate Committees I then called up the Memorial of Feuchtwanger, and a Memorial from Vermont praying for retrenchment and reform, and had them referred to the Committee of Ways and Means— They were referred to the Committee at the special Session, but not reported upon— I moved the reference of the Petition of Sherlock S. Gregory, praying for an act of Congress declaring him an alien, to the Committee on the Judiciary; observing that since the close of the special Session, I had received another Letter from him asking me to present again his petition, and to demand the action of the House upon it—a request which I had not felt myself at Liberty to deny— The memorial was referred.— I then presented the Petition of Nancy Ripley and 238 women of Plymouth, the principal town of the District that I have the honour to represent remonstrating against the annexation of Texas to this Union; and I moved that together with 190 Petitions, signed by more than twenty-thousand signers, and a still greater number of Petitions and Memorials presented at the same special Session by my Colleagues of the Massachusetts delegation, on the same subject, it be referred to a select Committee. Howard, of Maryland, Chairman of the Committee of Foreign Relations, moved that the reference should be to that Committee— I said that I had moved the reference to a select Committee by concert with my Colleagues, and with their unanimous assent— That if the Chairman of the Committee of foreign affairs persisted in his motion, I should feel myself bound to assign my reasons, for wishing to have the subject considered by a select Committee. The Speaker said if debate arose it must be postponed until to-morrow— Howard said it was a subject proper for the consideration of the Committee of foreign Relations, and he thought that the charge of persisting rather laid at my door.— Wise moved to lay both the motions, and all the Petitions and Memorials on the table, but the Speaker said that would not now be in order, but would be when the subject should be taken up to-morrow.— I next presented a petition for the abolition of Slavery and the Slave-trade in the District of Columbia, and moved its reference with all the Petitions on the same subject presented at the special Session to the Committee on the District of Columbia— Wise moved to lay all these upon the table, which was carried by yeas and nays 135 to 73— I offered several others with the same result, till Lawler objected to receiving one, but upon the yeas and nays the vote was 144 to 60 to receive, but it was immediately laid on the table— Then I presented a petition for the abolition of Slavery in the Territories; which again was laid on the table; by a vote of 127 to 73.— I then left the remaining anti-slavery petitions to be presented hereafter and presented a petition ofMorey on banking and currency, which at my motion was referred to the Committee of Ways and Means— The call for Petitions then proceeded as far as Pennsylvania, when about 3 O’Clock the House adjourned— This Evening Mr Phillebrown one of the Trustees of the second Presbyterian Church called on me, and said that the Trustees wished to have an interview with me, any Evening of next week at my convenience— I agreed to receive them Wednesday Evening
13. V. Wednesday

Publication this morning in the Globe and National Intelligencer, by six members of the Committee of Ways and Means against Richard Fletcher, member from Boston; and a member of the Committee— Mr Cushing called here this morning and told me that Mr Fletcher proposed giving an explanation, at the meeting of the House, and wished me to be in attendance— I rode to and from the Capitol— The meeting was opened with prayer by Mr Reese, the Chaplain of the House— After the reading of the Journal Mr Fletcher, referring to the Article in the Globe asked leave of the House to make an explanation which was granted.— The publication of the six members, was a passionate and elaborate attempt to prove the falsehood, of a Report in the Boston Atlas of a speech made by Fletcher at a Caucus in Faneuil Hall, in which he exposed the subserviency of the Committee of Ways and Means to the Executive. Mr Fletcher said that the report was incorrect as to details—that it was not made nor authorised by him— That he had not seen it till after it was published, and that he held himself not responsible for it— That the meeting at which he had spoken was not as the joint publication alledged to celebrate whig victories, but a regular annual meeting preparatory to the election— That he was there called upon to address his Constituents, and considered it his duty to inform them of the state of things here at the special Session of Congress from which he had just returned, and at which he a new and inexperienced member had been appointed by the Speaker a member of the Committee of Ways and Means— He had seen what he thought an improper influence exercised by the Executive Departments in the proceedings of the Committee, and of the House— He had said so to his constituents, and he still retained that opinion— But the report of his Speech was altogether inaccurate in the details, upon which the six signers of the publication in the Globe this morning, dwell so earnestly, and which he disavowed— He complained of the manner in which they had chosen to make this publication without first calling upon him to know whether he had spoken that which they had chosen to consider as personally offensive, and under these circumstances, he asked of the House to be discharged from further service on the Committee of Ways and Means— Cambreleng, Chairman of the Committee, Atherton of New-Hampshire, and Jones of Virginia, with leave of the House, answered Mr Fletcher, and insulted him with coarse and abusive language.— Jones began with great formality by asking if Fletcher avowed the report of his Speech at Faneuil-Hall, as published in the Boston Atlas, and said that what he should say would depend upon the answer to that question— Fletcher had already explicitly disavowed the details of that report; and did so again and then Jones went on and made his speech as he had gotten it by heart, as if Fletcher had avowed every word of the Report, and concluded by saying that it was a base falsehood— Fletcher asked me, if I thought he should reply to them, and I said No— They were six to one against him— The whole proceeding
proceeding was a party movement to bully down Fletcher and to brazen out their own delinquency—and there was in the House a majority to back them.— He could have given no suitable answer to Jones, without including in it the lie direct, and that would have produced violent disorder in the House, and probably violence out of it— He was discharged from further service on the Committee of Ways and Means— I spoke perhaps an hour, in support of the motion to refer the Memorials and Remonstrances against the annexation of Texas to this Union, to a select Committee, and not to the Committee of foreign affairs— Howard made no reply— Rhett of South-Carolina, and some others of the Slave-holders were ferocious for battle, and claimed the right to answer me— But Wise said I had made an intemperate speech, and renewed his motion of yesterday that all the Memorials concerning Texas, and both the motions, Howard’s and mine, for reference of them to Committees should be laid on the table— Which was carried 137 to 68— The call for Petitions was continued only from Pennsylvania to Virginia inclusive; and the House adjourned about 3. O Clock.— I rode to and from the Capitol. J. T. Buckingham the Editor of the Boston Courier came to my seat and invited me to write whatever I might please, to be published in his paper— Mr Pope of Kentucky paid us a morning visit; I was already on my way to the Capitol when he came, but the Ladies saw him— I was this evening under deep agitation of mind this evening, reflecting upon what had occurred this morning in the House, both to Mr Fletcher, and to myself— Meditating upon the course proper for me to pursue hereafter— Upon the moderation, which reason, and Christian charity and sound policy all concur to prescribe, and from which the unruliness of my tempers so often urges me to depart; and upon the firm and daring Spirit, which a sacred sense of duty enjoins upon me as equally indispensable to the cause almost exclusively committed to my trust—
14. V. Thursday

I have a whitlow on the forefinger of my right hand, without which it is impossible for me to write. It was so painful that I scarcely slept at all, last Night, and this day I could not put pen to paper; which is little less than the extinction of my life. H.R.U.S. Briggs was announced as the member of the Committee of Ways and Means appointed in the place of Mr Fletcher— He asked my advice whether he ought to accept, and at first, without much reflection, I said, yes. I saw no sufficient reason for him to decline, but I thought he was bound to take a firm and resolute stand in the Committee, and compel them to do their business in a very different manner— Soon after, Mr Phillips told me that Briggs had asked his advice, which was that he should not accept; and he thought no member of the delegation should consent to serve on that Committee; and I understood from him that other members of the delegation held the same opinion— I therefore told Briggs that in deference to the opinions of the other members he must consider my advice first given, as withdrawn— The calling of Petitions was resumed beginning with Virginia, and going through the remainder of the States and Territories
